entry.content:

entry.title: [Read Anything] Add PDF OCR for inaccessible PDFs
entry.content:
Add the kPDFOcr flag when turning accessibility for PDFs. PDF OCR

generates accessibility trees for inaccessible PDFs. That tree is then

sent to Reading mode, allowing users to view the PDF in the side panel.



PDF OCR currently treats one page of a PDF as one paragraph, so Reading

mode adds a line break between these pages to increase readability.



Replace EnableWebContentsOnlyAccessibilityMode() from WebContents with

EnableAccessibilityMode() to allow more control over what mode is added

before resetting accessibility.



Bug: 1266555

Change-Id: I5f2a9e70bab49db71a8aa7db3d70b5e9d22b972d

entry.title: Remove support for <obsolete> on histogram variants and suffixes.
entry.content:
There is still some supporting code for processing obsolete entries

that is not being removed, but this CL makes it so it's no longer

valid to add these tags to the XML entries.



I didn't remove all the supporting code partly because histograms

that are marked base="true" and that use suffixes are still

internally marked as obsolete. So once we move off of suffixes,

we can clean that out too.



Note: Existing obsolete variants and suffixes have already been

removed from Chromium.



Other things can still be marked as obsolete, in particular enums

but also entries in ukm.xml and actions.xml.

entry.title: [webauthn] Allow setting virtual authenticator BE/BS flags
entry.content:
Allow webauthn's virtual authenticator to to set default and per

credential backup eligibility (BE) and backup state (BS) flags. Expose

this through the devtools API.



Defaults can be set per authenticator using VirtualFidoDevice::State.

This sets the flags for both credentials created by executing the CTAP

make credential command, and credentials injected through State's

Inject* functions.



A future CL will expose this through webdriver.



See https://github.com/w3c/webauthn/pull/1999

entry.title: Update instance ID allocation for dragged link intent when max number of
entry.content:
instances is open



Currently, when the maximum number of Chrome instances is open, and a

link is dragged to create a new Chrome instance, the link intent is

launched in the "last accessed" instance. This leads to some

inconsistency in how the window in which such an intent is launched, is

chosen, because the access time of an instance is typically updated

when its activity is first created or when it resumes after a pause, and

does not account for actual access/use by the user within the window.



This CL updates the dragged link intent implementation to use the

instance ID of the current activity in this scenario, since it will

consistently launch such an intent in the window where the drag was

initiated, which would essentially also be the window that was

"accessed" by the user last.



Low-Coverage-Reason: COVERAGE_UNDERREPORTED The updates in the CL have sufficient unit and instrumentation coverage that are most likely not reflected here because of lack of test infrastructure to run these tests that are supported in Android S+.

Original change's description:

> Reland "[sync]Fix ShouldGetTypesWithUnsyncedDataFromSyncService integration test"

>

> This is a reland of commit 86e6619e36f23185c381d418c1e4016ddd3c1304

>

> Verified locally.

>

> The previous version had a race condition due to commit response not

> being processed. This CL fixes that by using a

> CommittedAllNudgedChangesChecker instead.

> > [sync]Fix ShouldGetTypesWithUnsyncedDataFromSyncService integration test

> >

> > Previously the test was flaky. This is because it relied on if there

> > exists some unsynced data for PREFERENCES. This is not super reliable

> > since many different components regularly interact with PREFERENCES and

> > there maybe something happening behind the scene which would give false

> > results when we expect there to be no unsynced data for PREFERENCES.

entry.title: Reland "[PageColors] Integration of PageColors feature with NativeTheme"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit da792e88b7ab6c96293af62d7ec62c7f6ecc51cf.

The issue was that we incorrectly assumed that

NativeTheme::ShouldUseDarkColors() would always return false initially.

However, on ChromeOS this function could sometimes return true.

To avoid this inconsistency, we explicitly set the desired value rather

than assuming anything about the native theme.



Original change's description:

> [PageColors] Integration of PageColors feature with NativeTheme

>

> This CL makes relevant state changes to the NativeTheme web instance

> when Page colors changes. This is done in the

> ColorSchemeNativeThemeObserver::OnNativeThemeUpdated method.

>

> In the ColorSchemeNativeThemeObserver::OnNativeThemeUpdated method,

> we preserves the current behavior if Page Colors is 'Off' and forced

> colors is false OR forced colors is true and Page Colors is

> 'High Contrast'. However, if that is not the case then:

>

> 1. Page Colors is 'Off' and forced colors is true, we override the

> state of forced colors for the native theme instance for web since the

> Page colors browser setting takes precedence over OS for web content.

> Here, we also watch for changes to the preferred color scheme and make

> sure we adjust the state appropriately.

> 2. Page Colors is one of the Contrast themes i.e. 'Dusk', 'Desert',

> 'Black', 'White'. Here, we set the forced colors state to true and

> other states appropriately for web content.

>

> This CL adds the color scheme observer as a native theme observer for

> Linux in order to receive the correct state changes from

> NativeThemeAura.

>

> Bug: 1231644

> Change-Id: I6792aadb9fead7a5d686c9cc0c67a29f986030ec

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4959835

> Reviewed-by: Peter Kasting

> Reviewed-by: Alison Maher

> Reviewed-by: Benjamin Beaudry

> Commit-Queue: Sam Davis Omekara

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1230166}

entry.title: Split magnifier effects into one backdrop zoom and one forward offset
entry.content:
The intent of backdrop filters was to be clipped to the layer's

bounds. When

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5002826

landed, it patched up a bug that was allowing certain cases to avoid

this clipping. Importantly, the touch selection magnifier was one of

these.



Assuming the backdrop filter could read outside of a layer's bounds,

the touch selection magnifier operated correctly. Discussing with

@kylechar, it seemed better to enforce that all backdrop filters keep

to this isolation rule than have a mode where UI layers can read

beyond their layer.



With that restriction, "backdrop offset" for the purposes of the

magnifier would be fundamentally broken because the content it needs

to magnify and where it has to be drawn are disjoint. To get around

this, the magnifier widget now places the "zoom" layer above the

region to be magnified by the Zoom background effect. Then it uses

a regular offset filter to translate everything to line up with the

rest of the magnifier widget's display, since forward filters are

allowed to move pixels from the layer bounds to elsewhere.



To get this to work, ui::Layer's background offset controls are

removed and replaced with a "layer offset" to reflect that the

cc::FilterOperation::OFFSET that it creates is now a regular filter

and not a backdrop filter.



ui::Layer now also exposes control over the cc::Layer's backdrop

filter bounds, which is a clip that impacts the backdrop filter

effect. Previously, SetRoundedCorners() was used, but this creates

a clip aligned with the original layer coordinates applied but applied

post-offset filter (so with a sufficient offset, it would clip out

everything of interest). Now the rounded corners are applied to the

output of the ZOOM backdrop effect before the offset filter and the

effect is carried along with it.



This also represents the first use case of a single RPDQ with

filters and backdrop filters, so there were several bugs and

simplifications that had to/could be made to SkiaRenderer.



Bug: b/312056981

entry.title: [iOS] Fix Payments Bottom Sheet's GPay logo
entry.content:
The GPay logo was resized using a draw operation in order to make

its actual height 28 pixels (from 24). This introduced visual

artefacts because of the low quality of the resulting image.



Instead, we now adjust the image's ratio (which, for native images

is usually 3.0) to keep the pixel data (3 * 24 = 72 pixels high) as

is and instead draw that in a larger region on the screen. So, in

this case, adjusting the ratio from 3 to (24/28) * 3 = ~2.5714...

will display the 72 pixels high pixel data in a 28 pixels high

region on the screen. This will yield better results than actually

resizing the pixel data to be 28 pixels high (and will save a draw

operation).



Bug: 1503583

entry.title: Rewire HoverButton's PressedCallback to support move-only callbacks.
entry.content:
PressedCallback will become non-copyable when it is updated to work with

OnceCallbacks. This causes problems since HoverButton uses its

PressedCallback for the actual underlying button, as well as passing a

copy to the button controller for it to handle additional events.



One potential solution is to use a trampoline RepeatingCallback and

populate HoverButton and HoverButtonController with two different

PressedCallback instances; this idea was discarded because:

- HoverButtonController gates a few behaviours based on whether the

supplied PressedCallback is null or not, so HoverButton would have to

conditionally create a trampoline RepeatingCallback only if the

PressedCallback is not null.

- however, a PressedCallback holding a OnceCallback will become null

after it is run, and there is no easy way of propagating that null

state up the PressedCallback chain.



Instead, the solution here is to store the original PressedCallback on

HoverButton itself, and allow HoverButtonController to grab a reference

to the PressedCallback when needed.



HoverButton still needs to pass a trampoline PressedCallback to the

actual underlying button, but this does not have the same issues with

propagating null state up the chain; the underlying button only cares

about the null state to avoid running a null callback.



Bug: 1326449

Change-Id: I37f087c4a43cff942a756b62dc1d5441670bc101

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5069913

Reviewed-by: Elly FJ

Commit-Queue: Daniel Cheng

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1231412}

entry.title: Reland "Remove redundant kOnDeviceModelService feature"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit c1401ba00ae4c25fb3556ad1159760107c6f0a6d



This switches the "features" target to a component to fix component

build issues.



Original change's description:

> Remove redundant kOnDeviceModelService feature

>

> We are now using kOptimizationGuideOnDeviceModel for most things, so

> switch to using that everywhere. This also removes the feature check

> when registering the service since all uses of the service are already

> feature checked.

entry.title: Fix null pointer dereference in AutoscrollController.
entry.content:
A fieldset element creates an anonymous block for its contents (see

LayoutFieldset::InsertedIntoTree), which may be passed as |scrollable|

to AutoscrollController::StartMiddleClickAutoscroll.



It seems we don't need to access scrollable->GetNode() in the first

place. We can just start the layout tree walk from scrollable itself.

entry.title: Mojo: Allow non-urgent messages in UrgentMessageScope
entry.content:
For Mojo methods without the [SupportsUrgent] attribute, there's a

DCHECK that we aren't in an UrgentMessageScope, mainly to prevent

developer errors. But non-urgent messages can be sent during

serialization while sending an urgent message, e.g. serializing

CommonNavigationParams during CommitNavigation can require cloning Mojo

endpoints, which requires calling that endpoint's Clone() method. This

CL removes the DCHECK to get around this.

entry.title: Implement auto sizes for lazy-loaded img
entry.content:
Auto Sizes allows developers to omit the sizes attribute (or set it to

sizes=auto) for lazy loaded image elements with srcset. For this use

case the image's width should be provided. The browser will use the

layout width of the image in order to select the source url from the

srcset.



Spec:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#parsing-a-sizes-attribute

https://whatpr.org/html/9493/images.html#parsing-a-sizes-attribute

entry.title: Allow sources to configure event-level epsilon
entry.content:
https://github.com/WICG/attribution-reporting-api/pull/1097



Although doing so is currently unnecessary for business logic, we

persist the value in the DB to ensure that we can retrieve it in the

future if needed. This also allows us to show it in the Attribution

Internals UI, which can aid in debugging.



We avoid a DB migration by treating absence of the corresponding proto

field as equivalent to the browser's maximum value. A DB version bump is

not needed, as prior to this change, the value was effectively a

constant used only when a source was newly stored, not after, so there

is no risk of a browser downgrade causing misinterpretation.



OBSOLETE_HISTOGRAM[Conversions.SourceRegistrationError9]=Replaced by Conversions.SourceRegistrationError10

entry.title: Reliably record notification permission revocations.
entry.content:
First, record if there is a ScopedRevocationReporter on the stack in the onContentSettingsChanged path. If there is one, record which PermissionSourceUI it came from. If there isn't one, manually call PermissionRevoked and record an 'UNIDENTIFIED' PermissionSourceUI.



We suspect that on Android, UNIDENTIFIED actually maps to ANDROID_SETTINGS, since permission toggles in Android are not handled in Chrome directly (i.e. in the OS Settings), and differences are detected and observed via the onContentSettingsChanged method. In these cases there is no explicit ScopedRevocationReporter created which means our current logging misses these events.



Bug: 1473118

entry.title: Add UMA metric for prefill requests.
entry.content:
This CL adds a metric to measure the "success" of a prefill request.

The metric is emitted whenever the user interacts with a form field

and OnAskForValuesToFill is triggered.



In its current form, the CL only records enums for cases in which

AutofillProviderAndroid decides not to attempt to show a bottom sheet:

1) If the form element has changed so substantially from the cached

form that it does not receive the same session id.

2) If another form was cached.

3) If there was not enough time to cache the form.



Once keyboard suppression is merged, a follow-up CL will add metrics

emission in the cases in which we do attempt to show a bottom sheet.

entry.title: Implement ResourceAttribution kMemorySummary queries
entry.content:
* Adds a MemoryMeasurementProvider owned by QueryScheduler.

QueryScheduler::RequestResults now invokes one or both of

CPUMeasurementMonitor and MemoryMeasurementProvider, depending on

the resource types in the request, and passes the results to a

BarrierCallback that invokes the final result callback once all

providers have returned results.

* Wraps the output of both CPUMeasurementMonitor and

MemoryMeasurementProvider in a QueryResult variant so both results

can be passed to the same QueryScheduler callback.

* Adds a FakeMemoryMeasurementDelegate for testing, and moves it and

the existing CPU delegate to measurement_delegates.h.

* Plumbs through SetDelegateFactoryForTesting to set the

MemoryMeasurementDelegate on QueryScheduler's

MemoryMeasurementProvider.

* Adds more compute gMock matchers, with better error output, to

gtest_util.h.

* Cleanup to keep CPUMeasurementMonitor consistent with

MemoryMeasurementProvider: removes redundant `cpu_measurement`

prefix from delegate-related members.

* Cleanup: removes unused CallbackQueryResultObserver from

query_scheduler_unittest.cc.



Bug: 1471683

entry.title: [sync] Avoid StopAndClear() in sync integration tests
entry.content:
It's not really needed and it is prone to exercising non-realistic

scenarios. Instead, the actual user-facing flow is to sign out and turn

sync off, which is already supported via SignOutPrimaryAccount().



Similarly, re-enabling sync (the feature) isn't well represented by

EnableSyncFeature(), removed in this patch. Instead, tests should

use SetupSync().



The downside is that some of these tests need to be ifdef-ed out on

Chrome Ash. This seems legit enough because those scenarios (involving

turning sync off) are much more exotic on this platform and exercise

other codepaths that don't require feature-specific browser tests.

entry.title: Add support for background source registrations
entry.content:
Add support for processing untrusted source registrations headers in the

browser process by adding three new methods to the

AttributionDataHostManager:

- NotifyBackgroundRegistrationStarted

- NotifyBackgroundRegistrationData

- NotifyBackgroundRegistrationCompleted



These methods will be used in a follow up CL which adds an attribution

hook to the KeepAliveUrlLoader.



Support for trigger registrations via these methods will be added in a

follow up CL.



The feature is gated by blink::features::kKeepAliveInBrowserMigration

and blink::features::kAttributionReportingInBrowserMigration.

entry.title: [ios] Fix incorrect assertion when using multiple windows on iPad
entry.content:
On iPad, it is possible to have multiple windows, and thus Browsers,

open at the same time. This means it is possible for another Browser

to be dirty after loading the session for one Browser.



This means that it is possible for `dirty_web_state_lists_` to be

non-empty after removing the current Browser's WebStateList from it.

Handle this case by removing the DCHECK() and only cancelling the

timer if the list is empty.

entry.content:
This metric will give us an idea on how good is PWM at filling

the username form in the sign-in UFF flow. We will use that metric

entry.title: Allow non-percentages for hsl and hwb
entry.content:
HSL and HWB have comma-less, "non-legacy" formats now with

css-color-4. In these formats saturation, lightness, whiteness and

blackness no longer need to be in percentages, but instead can be

bare numbers which get divided by 100 to represent percentages.



https://drafts.csswg.org/css-color-4/#typedef-modern-hsl-syntax

"""

The next two arguments are the saturation and lightness, respectively. For saturation, 100% or 100 is a fully-saturated, bright color, and 0% or 0 is a fully-unsaturated gray. For lightness, 50% or 50 represents the "normal" color, while 100% or 100 is white and 0% or 0 is black.

"""



Some colors that were assumed to be "invalid" for relative color use

bare numbers for hsl/hwb and thus are no longer invalid.



Bug: 1505787

Change-Id: Ie7fec239d0422da54a3d8ee0e46e64b1bee73fe2

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5067499

entry.title: Reland "Allow createEncodedStreams on PCs without encodedInsertableStreams param"
entry.content:
Change since previous: Reduce number of frames/packets waited for in

insertable-streams web test and add it to SlowTests. See Patchset

1 -> Patchset 5 diff.



This is a reland of commit e5518aa87b722a83596d1fb2a7506d0ab76f1207



Original change's description:

> Allow createEncodedStreams on PCs without encodedInsertableStreams param

>

> Allow creating Encoded Transforms for any Receivers and Senders, so

> long as createEncodedStreams() is called by JS synchronously after

> sender/receiver creation. This is achieved by setting up a WebRTC

> transform on all transceivers, but "short circuiting" it if JS hasn't

> set up its own transform within an event loop spin of creation. This

> will make the transform just pass frames to be transformed directly back

> without invoking the cost of a thread hop or any JS work.

>

> The existing behaviour (dropping all frames until a JS transform is

> installed) is preserved for PCs created with {encodedInsertableStreams:

> true}.

>

> This implements the algorithm defined in https://www.w3.org/TR/2023/WD-webrtc-encoded-transform-20231012/#stream-creation,

> but for the Chromium createEncodedStreams() method, improving

> conformance incrementally.

>

>

> Bug: 1502781

> Change-Id: Ie36d8ed8f431afa97307030646d3b207bf14cf7a

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5040731

> Commit-Queue: Tony Herre

> Reviewed-by: Guido Urdaneta

> Reviewed-by: Harald Alvestrand

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1230611}



Bug: 1502781

Change-Id: I70b366f375e1b6c8e90567f5c994423fd738c8fa

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5077034

entry.title: Cleanup: Deprecate unused fields in Sync's TabNavigation proto
entry.content:
The newly-deprecated and no-longer-populated fields are:

* navigation_redirect

* last_navigation_redirect_url

* replaced_navigation

* task_id

* ancestor_taks_id

* page_language

* blocked_state



All of these were populated in Chromium, but never read again.

Some of them required a bunch of plumbing, which is also removed.



The fields are marked as deprecated rather than removed entirely

because there are still server-side references to them.

entry.title: [FSA] Persistent Permissions Page Info UI MVP Implementation
entry.content:
Implements the approved, "MVP" version of the Page Info UI for File System, which is required for the initial launch of the FSA Persistent Permissions feature, behind a flag.



Please note that this UI introduces a "new" pattern, it will be modified in a followup change, building off of the work started in

crrev.com/c/4930436. This planned and required followup change will

match the approved UX mockup for the full rollout version of this

feature when the flag is removed, and will also match the existing

Page Info UI pattern for One Time Permissions.

entry.title: Default page margin of 0.5in for WPT print reftests.
entry.content:
https://web-platform-tests.org/writing-tests/print-reftests.html still

doesn't mention any margins (just says to use a page size of 5 by 3

inches), but Firefox also uses 0.5 inch margins, and some tests expect

this too. Furthermore,

https://github.com/web-platform-tests/rfcs/blob/master/rfcs/print_test.md

wants us to use 0.5 inch margins as well.



Update some documentation pertaining to page size, to clarify that this

is just the *default* page size, which may be overridden using @page CSS

rules.



This fixed two tests that were assumed to fail because of subpixel

rounding issues, but this was apparently wrong.



A couple of tests (written by me) had to be updated because of this

change (because they assumed 0 margins).



Bug: 1090628

Change-Id: Ib12af644e544ad51be5750dba98f97bfddf38bdb

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5067421

Commit-Queue: Morten Stenshorne

Reviewed-by: Peter Beverloo

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1231300}

entry.title: Reland "[soft-navigations] move startTime to processing end"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit eab7d4b6462aee496860f0dbe342066bd342f5b9



It better takes into account event bubbling, and the fact we see

multiple tasks in a single EventScope in those cases. It also tests this case specifically.



Original change's description:

> [soft-navigations] move startTime to processing end

>

> This CL aligns the implementation with [1], and sets the soft navigation

> start time to be the processingEnd of the relevant earlier event.

>

> It also cleans up a few bits of code that became useless, as well as

> issues around PerInteractionData copying that were buggy yet hidden

> before the timing of setting the different attributes was changed.

>

>

> [1] https://github.com/WICG/soft-navigations/issues/14

>

> Change-Id: Id9f7ebf9f372a334a206f99258c882f10eeda2c5

> Bug: 1505059

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5059108

> Reviewed-by: Ian Clelland

> Commit-Queue: Yoav Weiss

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1230490}
